author: By Karen Zraick
title: A Tough Start for Greenpeace in Court Fight With Pipeline Giant
description: The environmental group, battling a multimillion-dollar lawsuit over protests against the Dakota Access Pipeline, told the court it can’t get a fair trial.
content: The opening week of the landmark trial of Greenpeace in a multimillion-dollar lawsuit by Energy Transfer over the Dakota Access Pipeline protests did not bode well for the defense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles, Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
title: ‘Full on Fight Club’: How Trump Is Crushing U.S. Climate Policy
description: President Trump has quickly transformed America’s approach to the environment, withholding funds and stretching the limits of presidential power.
content: In a few short weeks, President Trump has severely damaged the government’s ability to fight climate change, upending American environmental policy with moves that could have lasting implications for the country, and the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Wehner
title: ‘My Problem Was Not With Grief With a Capital G. My Problem Was That Eric Was Dead.’
description: A Q&A with the theologian Nick Wolterstorff.
content: Nicholas Wolterstorff is among the most prominent Christian philosophers of the 20th century. I learned of him when I read his deeply affecting, searingly honest book, “Lament for a Son,” an expression of his profound grief in the aftermath of the death of his 25-year-old son, Eric, in a mountain-climbing accident. “To the most agonizing question I have ever been asked,” Mr. Wolterstorff wrote, “I do not know the answer. I do not know why God would watch him fall. I do not know why God would watch me wounded. I cannot even guess. My wound is an unanswered question. The wounds of all humanity are an unanswered question.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teddy Rosenbluth
title: Federal Officials Underplaying Measles Vaccination, Experts Say
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has described the outbreak in West Texas last week as a “top priority.” But he has not explicitly encouraged Americans to get vaccinated.
content: In a first test of the Trump administration’s ability to respond to an infectious disease emergency, its top health official has shied away from one of the government’s most important tools, experts said on Sunday: loudly and directly encouraging parents to get their children vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Saslow and Erin Schaff
title: She’s a Foot Soldier in America’s Losing War With Chronic Disease
description: In places like Mingo County, W.Va., where working-age people are dying at record rates, a nurse learns what it takes to make America healthy.
content: Sam Runyon navigated to the house by memory as she reviewed her patient’s file, a “problem list” of medications and chronic diseases that went on for several pages. Sam, a 45-year-old nurse, had already seen Cora Perkins survive two types of cancer. During previous appointments, she had found Cora’s arms turning blue from diabetes, or her ankles swollen from congestive heart failure, or her stomach cramping from hunger with no fresh food left in the house. It had been a week since Sam’s last visit, and she wondered if anyone had come or gone through the front door since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: The 19th-Century Country Houses of Europe’s Jewish Elite
description: A lavish photo book collects images old and new of elaborate estates, manors, chateaus and Schlosses in the European countryside.
content: “To enter into high society,” Benjamin Disraeli wrote, “a man must either have blood, a million or a genius.” As soon as he was able to convert his own genius into power and fortune, the future British prime minister — who’d been raised by Sephardic Jews in London — bought Hughenden Manor, a “gentleman’s residence” on 750 hilly acres in the English countryside. Financially, Disraeli could barely afford to buy the place; politically and socially, he couldn’t afford not to. A house and lands were the necessary props to his ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Europe Races to Repair a Split Between the U.S. and Ukraine
description: European leaders pledge to assemble a “coalition of the willing” to develop a plan for ending Ukraine’s war with Russia, which they hope could win the backing of a skeptical President Trump.
content: European leaders raced on Sunday to salvage Ukraine’s ruptured relationship with the United States, with Britain and France assembling a “coalition of the willing” to develop a plan for ending Ukraine’s war with Russia. They hope this effort will win the backing of a skeptical President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Trump Moves to Increase Logging in National Forests
description: The president wants to circumvent environmental regulations to expand timber production, something sought by homebuilders and the construction industry.
content: President Trump has promised to “drill, baby, drill.” Now, he also wants to log.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Underrated Nominee
description: Plus, news about David Leonhardt and the Morning.
content: My colleagues and I started this newsletter almost five years ago, in the early weeks of the Covid lockdowns. And running it has been one of the best jobs I’ve had. I’m grateful to all of you who make time in your day for The Morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Chapman
title: His Pitch to Save His Career: A Podcast About His Dead Best Friend
description: In Jeremy Gordon’s novel, “See Friendship,” a journalist reinvestigates his past, only to discover the story he was told about his friend’s death wasn’t true.
content: In the decade since the hit show “Serial” turned the name “Adnan” into a dinner-party mononym, a new protagonist archetype has emerged: the podcaster. Often these narrators play amateur detectives pursuing true-crime cases involving violence against young women (“I Have Some Questions for You,” by Rebecca Makkai, and “Sadie,” by Courtney Summers). Other times, the narrator’s pulled into manosphere buffoonery (“Friend of the Pod,” by Sam Lipsyte). Now we have Jeremy Gordon’s debut novel, “See Friendship,” whose reluctant podcaster is adrift and full of anxiety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Say Yes Without Words
description: Harrison Walden never tires.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: A Papal Primer That’s Fiction, but Also Rings True
description: “Conclave,” an Oscar nominee, has provided a peek at the Vatican’s secret rituals at a time when the faithful are praying that life will not imitate art.
content: After back-to-back wins for best picture at the Screen Actors Guild Awards and at Britain’s equivalent of the Oscars, the papal thriller “Conclave” has a chance at a hat-trick on Sunday at the Academy Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Trump Signs Order to Designate English as Official Language of the U.S.
description: The order did not require changes to federal programs but was a victory for America’s English-only movement, which has ties to efforts to restrict immigration and bilingual education.
content: President Trump signed an order designating English as the official language of the United States, the White House said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wendy S. Walters
title: Taming the ‘Howling Infinite’: ‘Moby Dick’ Comes to the Met’s Stage
description: Jake Heggie and Gene Scheer’s 2010 adaptation of Melville’s unruly novel opens this week at the Metropolitan Opera.
content: When “Moby Dick” opens at the Metropolitan Opera this week, audiences will experience a deeply American story of unchecked ambition, fomented grievances and a self-destructive desire for revenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,353
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, March 3, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: 4 Dead in Fiery Chain-Reaction Crash in Arizona
description: Investigators are exploring whether blowing dust contributed to the 12-vehicle crash on Saturday that also left two people in critical condition.
content: Four people are dead and two others are in critical condition after a chain-reaction crash involving 12 vehicles on an Arizona highway on Saturday afternoon, possibly caused by blowing dust, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Goldstein
title: 320 Years Before the Muppets, the English Took Manhattan
description: In “Taking Manhattan,” Russell Shorto pays close attention to the darker aspects of colonial life on the island at the center of the world.
content: The British are coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: The 9 People Who Check In to Every ‘White Lotus’
description: The exotic settings change from season to season in this HBO hit, but the characters stay the same.
content: A luxury hotel marries the exotic and the familiar: The location may be new and the fruits at the breakfast buffet varied, but the thread count of the sheets, the indulgence of the staff, the sumptuousness of the spa — these remain the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold, Margot Sanger-Katz and Jeremy Singer-Vine
title: DOGE Claims Credit for Killing Contracts That Were Already Dead
description: Elon Musk’s group claimed credit for canceling procurement agreements that had been completed years earlier, the latest in a string of public errors on its site.
content: While George W. Bush was president, the U.S. Coast Guard signed a contract to get administrative help from a company in Northern Virginia. It paid $144,000, and the contract was completed by June 30, 2005.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: ‘Moon Dust on Our Boots’: Texas Company’s Blue Ghost Lands on Lunar Surface
description: Firefly Aerospace’s robotic vehicle became the second privately built spacecraft to make a soft landing on the moon. It could soon be joined by two more private lunar landers.
content: A robotic spacecraft from an American startup gently set down on a lava plain on the moon’s near side early Sunday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler, Stephen Castle, Aurelien Breeden and Jeanna Smialek
title: Here is the latest.
description: Declaring that “we are at a crossroads in history,” Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain said on Sunday that European countries would ramp up their military spending and assemble a “coalition of the willing” to defend any peace declared in Ukraine.
content: Declaring that “we are at a crossroads in history,” Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain said on Sunday that European countries would ramp up their military spending and assemble a “coalition of the willing” to defend any peace declared in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Behind the Scenes at Oscars Rehearsals: Gym Shorts and Girl Scout Cookies
description: Oprah Winfrey, Goldie Hawn and Whoopi Goldberg showed up for a run-through the day before the ceremony.
content: Oprah Winfrey’s eyeglasses glinted in the stage lights at the Dolby Theater in Los Angeles. Whoopi Goldberg scuttled up beside her, hands in the pockets of her balloon-leg trousers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Halts Aid to Gaza and Proposes New Framework for an End to the War
description: Israel has called for Hamas to accept a temporary extension of the existing cease-fire deal, and to release more hostages.
content: Israel announced on Sunday that it was immediately halting the entry of all goods and humanitarian assistance into Gaza, trying to force Hamas into accepting a temporary extension of the cease-fire in the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: Vesuvius Erupted, but When Exactly?
description: Two thousand years on, scholars still don’t agree on the day the destruction of Pompeii began. Two new studies only fan the fire.
content: When Mount Vesuvius erupted in A.D. 79, fiery avalanches of ash and pumice assaulted Pompeii, displacing some 15,000 inhabitants and killing at least 1,500 more. Volcanic debris “poured across the land,” wrote the Roman lawyer Pliny the Younger, and blanketed the town in a darkness “like the black of closed and unlighted rooms.” Within two days Pompeii had vanished, leaving little more than a legend until 1748, when the chance discovery of a water line prompted the first deliberate excavation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: Problems With New California Bar Exam Enrage Test Takers and Cloud Their Futures
description: Many aspiring lawyers could not access the test and cited delays or other issues. A lawmaker has called for an investigation.
content: Even under normal circumstances, the California bar exam is one final harrowing hurdle before aspiring lawyers can practice. But last week was worse than any other, as they were thrown into limbo by technical glitches, delays and what many said were bizarrely written questions on a revamped test that didn’t match anything in preparation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany, Tally Abecassis, John Woo, Aaron Esposito and Catherine Anderson
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Cryptocurrency Scam That Turned a Small Town Against Itself’
description: How did a successful, financially sophisticated banker gamble his community’s money away?
content: Jim Tucker could hardly believe what he was hearing. It sounded like fiction, a nightmare too outlandish for an unassuming town like his.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nazaneen Ghaffar
title: Severe Storms in the South Could Disrupt Mardi Gras Celebrations
description: Forecasters warn of intense storms that could unleash damaging winds, large hail and tornadoes in parts of Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi on Tuesday.
content: As Mardi Gras celebrations prepare to take over New Orleans on Tuesday, the South faces a mounting weather threat, with forecasters warning of intense storms that could bring damaging winds, large hail and the potential for tornadoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: My Red Carpet Quest: A Two-Year Search for Steve
description: A reporter, after several attempts, managed to pin down the man who makes the celebrated carpet for the Oscars each year.
content: Steve Olive was my white whale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Reprises the Trump-Zelensky Oval Office Face-Off
description: Mike Myers, as Elon Musk, adds an extra measure of crazy to an already bizarre moment in MAGA-era foreign policy.
content: A shockingly combative White House meeting between President Trump and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine may have precipitated a diplomatic crisis and signaled a fissure in the longstanding relationship between the United States and Europe. But the incident provided ample grist for the satirical mill on “Saturday Night Live” in the first new broadcast after its 50th anniversary celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Ana Swanson
title: Professor, Scrutinized for Ties to China, Sues to Get His Job Back
description: Feng Tao, who was tenured at the University of Kansas, was cleared of charges brought under a discontinued Trump program aimed at Chinese spying.
content: The chemistry professor’s nightmare seemed to finally be over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Becoming Tom Ford
description: The inside story of how Haider Ackermann came to be the man for the brand and what he has planned.
content: One evening in late January, Haider Ackermann, the new designer at Tom Ford, was tucked into a velvet banquette at La Reserve, the discreet, tryst-worthy hotel not far from the Élysée Palace in Paris. He was doing his best impression of Tom Ford, the man.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transgender Rights Are Human Rights
description: Readers respond to a guest essay by Jennifer Finney Boylan and an editorial. Also: “Sorry” about America; lying to children.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Syrian Forces Deployed in Majority-Druse Town After Clash
description: An uneasy calm prevailed in the town on the outskirts of Damascus on Sunday, two days after a gunfight between local men and security forces.
content: Syrian security forces were deployed across a predominately Druse town on the outskirts of Damascus, the capital, early Sunday, two days after a gunfight between government officers and armed men from a local neighborhood left one person dead and several others wounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Heath
title: The Democrats Need a Project 2029. Here’s a Start.
description: A call for a reform project that is ambitious, radical and iconoclastic yet grounded in a genuine desire to fix the problems of American governance.
content: President Trump’s outright war on the administrative state has put Democrats in a difficult position, since their core brand is that they are the pro-government party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Designers Really Want Us to Wear Fur
description: Or at least something that looks like fur. The message from the Milan runways was loud and clear.
content: There was really no way around it: A show celebrating 100 years of Fendi was always going to mean celebrating fur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young and Hisako Ueno
title: Japan Fights Its Largest Wildfire in More Than 30 Years
description: The fire, in a forested area of the coastal city of Ofunato, killed at least one person and prompted evacuation orders for thousands of residents.
content: Japan’s largest wildfire in more than three decades was burning through a forested area of a small coastal city on Sunday after killing at least one person, damaging dozens of homes and prompting evacuation orders for thousands of residents, fire officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Cuomo Jolts New York’s Mayoral Race as His Challengers Attack
description: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo hit the campaign trail on Sunday. The other candidates are already trying to stop his momentum.
content: For months, the race for mayor of New York City felt stuck in suspended animation. No more.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 2, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 2, 2025.
content: An article on Page 22 this weekend about Parker Posey misspells the surname of an actress. She is Michelle Monaghan, not Moynahan. And the article misspelled the surname of a filmmaker. He is Greg Mottola, not Motolla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Rubio Bypasses Congress to Send Israel $4 Billion in Arms
description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s emergency declaration calls for sending 2,000-pound bombs and other weapons to Israel as the war in Gaza continues.
content: Secretary of State Marco Rubio has invoked “emergency authorities” to bypass Congress and send $4 billion in weapons to Israel, the second time in a month that the Trump administration has skirted the process of congressional approval for sending arms to the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, David E. Sanger and Helene Cooper
title: Hegseth Orders Pentagon to Stop Offensive Cyberoperations Against Russia
description: The defense secretary’s instructions, which were given before President Trump’s blowup with the Ukrainian president, are apparently part of an effort to draw Russia into talks on the war.
content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has ordered U.S. Cyber Command to halt offensive operations against Russia, according to a current official and two former officials briefed on the secret instructions. The move is apparently part of a broader effort to draw President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia into talks on Ukraine and a new relationship with the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: Oscars 2025 Winners: Full List
description: The complete list of winners at the 97th annual Academy Awards.
content: Read the highlights of the 2025 Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Yan
title: Black Churches Are Awarded $8.5 Million in Grants for Preservation
description: The initiative to save historic Black churches has aided 108 congregations since 2023.
content: Black churches across the country recently were awarded more than $8 million in grants, part of an effort to preserve buildings that played significant roles in Black history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Hvistendahl and Joy Dong
title: As Musk Consolidates Power in the U.S., His Mother Is in Demand Overseas
description: Maye Musk, a model and a public speaker, recently headlined a government conference in Dubai and endorsed a slew of products in China.
content: In the past six months, Maye Musk, the mother of Elon Musk, has been to China, Kazakhstan and the United Arab Emirates, visits that come as foreign leaders are jockeying for influence over the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael R. Jackson
title: Is ‘Wicked’ Really a Resistance Musical?
description: Does Elphaba have anything to do with the political moment in America? Or are we engaging in progressive magical thinking?
content: I first saw “Wicked” in 2003, when I was 22 and studying musical theater writing at N.Y.U. As a nascent musical theater writer, I was impressed by its craftsmanship and unusual premise: that the cackling, green-faced Wicked Witch of the West most of us know from the 1939 film has a name: Elphaba Thropp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson and Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Halts All Aid Into Gaza as Cease-Fire Expires
description: The move came hours after Israel had proposed a temporary extension of the truce, though one with terms that Hamas is unlikely to accept.
content: Israel announced on Sunday morning that it was halting the entry of all goods and humanitarian assistance into Gaza immediately, hours after proposing a temporary extension of the now-expired cease-fire with Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teddy Wayne
title: A Turbulent Road Trip to Manhood, Loaded Gun in Tow
description: Two teenage boys set out north with few plans and plenty of frustrations in Vijay Khurana’s novel, “The Passenger Seat.”
content: “The Passenger Seat,” Vijay Khurana’s unsettling and powerful debut novel, follows two teenagers on the fragile cusp of manhood in a Canadian border town. Adam lives with his “failure” of a father, a former boatbuilder now delivering pizza, and hasn’t seen his mother in six years. Teddy’s well-off family is ostensibly functional but atomized, his mother barely concealing her affair, his father in blithe denial. Teddy is handsome, socially accepted and has a girlfriend he’s not particularly close with, a source of envy for Adam, who repels the opposite sex with his coarse appearance and coarser manners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Paulina Villegas and Daniele Volpe
title: Trump Threats and Mexico’s Crackdown Hit Mexican Cartel
description: Several cartel operatives said that for the first time in years, they genuinely feared arrest or death at the hands of the authorities.
content: One cartel leader says he’s trying to figure out how to protect his family in case the American military strikes inside Mexico. Another says he’s already gone into hiding, rarely leaving his home. Two young men who produce fentanyl for the cartel say they have shut down all their drug labs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Martin E. Marty, Influential Religious Historian, Dies at 97
description: A staunch champion of pluralism, he was described in Time magazine as “the most influential living interpreter of religion in the U.S.”
content: Martin E. Marty, a pre-eminent religious historian, prolific author, dependable exponent of mainstream Protestantism and staunch champion of pluralism, died on Tuesday  in Minneapolis. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pragati K.B
title: Avalanche Buries Road Workers’ Camp in India, Killing 8
description: Rescuers working in extreme conditions evacuated 46 other construction workers trapped beneath feet of snow.
content: Eight road construction workers died after becoming trapped under an avalanche in northern India, the Indian Army said on Sunday. Rescuers operating in several feet of snow evacuated 46 other workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Linda Qiu
title: Horticulturists, Biologists, Engineers: Federal ‘Bloat’ or Valued Experts?
description: President Trump’s effort to remake the government is a direct challenge to a decades-long effort to build a civil service stocked with experts. Critics say it will backfire.
content: The National Plant Germplasm System, a vast federal collection of seeds, roots, branches and stems, is probably unknown to most Americans. But to Rachel Spaeth the system is a “living library” — and America’s safeguard against “famine on a global scale.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Guerchom Ndebo
title: Why Congo’s Vast Army Is Struggling to Fight a Far Smaller Militia
description: The latest conflict in eastern Congo has exposed endemic weaknesses in the country’s military, long known for corruption, extortion and abuse.
content: Its soldiers are underpaid and underarmed. Its ranks are riddled with factions pursuing their own interests. And successive presidents are said to have kept it weak for fear of a coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Celebrities Start Partying Before the Oscars and Keep Going All Weekend
description: Jeff Bezos, Kim Kardashian, Demi Moore, Mick Jagger and others gathered in festive moods in the lead-up to Hollywood’s biggest night.
content: The billionaire Jeff Bezos sat inside the Polo Lounge at the Beverly Hills Hotel on Saturday night with his fiancée, Lauren Sanchez, who carried a silver purse in the shape of a spaceship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diane Harris
title: Do You Know How Much Your Spouse Makes? Some Couples Are Clueless.
description: Many couples are surprisingly unaware about key aspects of each other’s finances — and that can hurt them. Here’s how to get on the same page.
content: Here’s a pop quiz for married couples.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Favorites, Scandals and History-Makers: Your 6-Point Guide to the Oscars
description: From the most competitive races to the lasting controversies, here’s a guide to becoming an instant expert.
content: When the Ralph Fiennes-led papal thriller “Conclave” secured the highest honor at the 31st Screen Actors Guild Awards last weekend, it seemed like a strong indicator that it would prevail in the best picture category at the Academy Awards on Sunday night. After all, the last three winners of SAG’s top prize — “Oppenheimer,” “Everything Everywhere All at Once” and “CODA” — all won the best picture statuette at the Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Monday Briefing: Europe Pledges to Support Ukraine
description: Plus, remote taste testing.
content: The British prime minister, Keir Starmer, declared yesterday that “we are at a crossroads in history,” and announced that European countries would assemble a “coalition of the willing” to defend Ukraine against Russia. Read more here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: What to Know About Israel’s Decision to Halt Aid to Gaza
description: The move was apparently part of a bid to force Hamas into accepting a temporary extension of a cease-fire and releasing more hostages.
content: Israel on Sunday announced that it would stop all goods and humanitarian aid from entering Gaza, a draconian move that disrupted the existing, agreed-upon framework for negotiating a permanent end to the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Following the ‘Anora’ Star, as He Rides the Oscar Wave
description: Hollywood newcomer Mark Eydelshteyn compared the days before the ceremony to the ocean, and “you have to be a surfer.”
content: Mark Eydelshteyn was jolted awake on Saturday by two stylists who rapped on the door of his hotel room, then entered with several racks of clothing and a very large dog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Todd Heisler
title: An Immigrant Neighborhood Where Trump Made Inroads Now Fears ICE Raids
description: In Corona, a once-vibrant New York City enclave home to generations of Latino immigrants, the threat of mass deportations has made many residents afraid to go outside.
content: The taco joint just around the corner from Corona Plaza, the beating heart of one of New York City’s largest Latin American neighborhoods, fell quiet in the days after President Trump was inaugurated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: Oscars Red Carpet 2025: All the Stars, All the Looks
description: Ariana Grande, Timothée Chalamet and Selena Gomez arrived in season-defining style.
content: The carpet outside the Dolby Theater in Los Angeles was classic red. The stars who appeared at the 97th Academy Awards wore colors from all across the spectrum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 631
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, March 3, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Oscars 2025 Takeaways: ‘Anora’ Dominates Top Awards
description: The movie, which cost only $6 million to make, won best picture and four other Oscars.
content: The genre-hopping “Anora,” a nonchalant take on sex work filled with shouted profanities, won best picture and four other Oscars at the 97th Academy Awards. It was a nontraditional choice that reflected an academy in transition — younger, edgier and not terribly concerned about ticket sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yanzhong Huang
title: America Is Dangerously Ignorant of What’s Going On in China
description: Decisions on U.S. policy toward China are being made based on diminishing insight into the country’s internal dynamics.
content: In December 2022, China’s government abruptly ditched its strict Covid-19 pandemic controls after thousands of citizens protested against the social and economic pain they were causing. It was a complete surprise: Despite closely tracking the situation from afar, I and many other China watchers had failed to anticipate this sudden and major shift in government policy which deeply affected life in China and the country’s openness to the rest of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Coleman and Mark Bonamo
title: In N.Y.C.’s Ukrainian Enclaves, Trump’s Rebuke Stirs Complex Feelings
description: The president and vice president’s berating of Volodymyr Zelensky was greeted with a mix of support and outrage.
content: Brighton Beach, a Slavic enclave in Brooklyn where Ukrainians outnumber Russians two to one, voted overwhelmingly for President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Vesuvius Turned One Victim’s Brain to Glass
description: Heat from the eruption in A.D. 79 was so intense that it vitrified the brain tissue of one unfortunate Herculaneum resident, a new study confirms.
content: Five years ago Italian researchers published a study on the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in A.D. 79. that detailed how one victim of the blast, a male presumed to be in his mid 20s, had been found nearby in the seaside settlement of Herculaneum. He was lying facedown and buried by ash on a wooden bed in the College of the Augustales, a public building dedicated to the worship of Emperor Augustus. Some scholars believe that the man was the center’s caretaker and was asleep at the time of the disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Elon Musk’s Internet: So Based, Much Wow. So Cringe?
description: Mr. Musk uses online slang to marshal his 200 million social media followers in support of his efforts to gut the federal government. But he might be reaching his limits.
content: In 2010, a woman in Sakura, Japan, posted photos of her well-manicured Shiba Inu to her digital journal. The dog, Kabosu, shot her owner a wide-eyed glance, a comic image that quickly jumped from Tumblr to Twitter to Facebook and to the rest of the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: What Would the Church Say About End-of-Life Decisions for a Pope?
description: Francis has weighed in publicly before on ethics for end-of-life medical situations, but it is unknown whether he has made known his own wishes should he face such a crossroads.
content: A respiratory crisis suffered by Pope Francis on Friday during his two-week hospitalization for pneumonia has added urgency to a delicate, and uncomfortable, question worrying many in the church: What would happen if the pope remains in critical condition for an extended period, with his health worsening, his faculties fading, his quality of life deteriorating?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Angie Stone, Hip-Hop Pioneer Turned Neo-Soul Singer, Dies at 63
description: After having success as a member of the Sequence, an early female rap group, she re-emerged in the 1990s as a practitioner of sultry, laid-back R&B.
content: Angie Stone, a hip-hop pioneer in the late 1970s with the Sequence, one of the first all-female rap groups, who later switched gears as a solo R&B star with hits like “No More Rain (In This Cloud)” and “Wish I Didn’t Miss You,” died on Saturday in Montgomery, Ala. She was 63.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Troops, Cartels and China: What Mexico Is Doing to Stave Off Tariffs
description: Aiming to appease President Trump, Mexico is hitting China with tariffs, handing cartel leaders over to the United States and using C.I.A. intelligence to hunt down others.
content: Mexico braced for the worst when President Trump threatened steep tariffs on its exports. But as a deadline looms, Mexico’s leaders hope they have found a formula for staving off tariffs by moving decisively on several fronts to appease Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eamon Dolan
title: I Broke Up With My Abusive Mother. I Don’t Regret That Decision.
description: Estrangement is often the most moral option. What’s immoral is encouraging people to remain in relationships that hurt them.
content: Twelve years ago, I broke up with my mother. She beat me and my siblings hundreds of times in our youth, and she inflicted on us an array of other behaviors that qualified as emotional abuse — from insults and tirades to humiliation and gaslighting. Her abuse continued into my 40s, when, after years of futile efforts to change the dynamic between us, I severed ties with her for good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Trump Is Doing Real Damage to America
description: The president’s about-face on Ukraine has taught our allies a lesson they won’t be unlearning anytime soon.
content: President Trump is doing damage to America that could take a generation or more to repair. The next election cannot fix what Trump is breaking. Neither can the one after that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: After He Ran a Cartoon on the War in Gaza, Gannett Fired Him
description: Tony Doris, the editorial page editor at The Palm Beach Post, was fired after he selected a cartoon that drew criticism from a nearby Jewish organization.
content: Tony Doris said he never shied away from controversy during his lengthy career at The Palm Beach Post, a Pulitzer Prize-winning newspaper in the backyard of President Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Europe Is Left With Hard Choices as Trump Sours on Ukraine
description: European leaders have been working to support Ukraine and beef up their own defenses. But the blowup between President Trump and Ukraine’s president on Friday made those goals more urgent.
content: European leaders have dealt with President Trump’s return to office by trying to keep him cooperating on Ukraine while pushing to ramp up their own defense spending so they are less reliant on an increasingly fickle America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Johanna Lemola
title: Finland Lets Ship Leave, Two Months After Suspected Sabotage
description: The Finnish authorities suggested that the ship, which was seized on suspicion of involvement in the cutting of undersea cables, had ties to Russia.
content: The Finnish authorities said on Sunday that they had released an oil tanker seized in December over suspicions that it had deliberately cut vital undersea cables but that a criminal investigation into the episode would continue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: The Streaming Rush to Turn Scripture Into Scripts
description: After the success of “The Chosen,” Amazon and Netflix are converting Bible stories into films and TV shows with “Game of Thrones”-style intrigue and romantic comedy elements.
content: A once-beloved king slips into madness as wary confidants surround him, breathless for his next maneuver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: This Chicken Satay Is Superb
description: Naz Deravian’s recipe, adapted from one by Pailin Chongchitnant, is a vibrantly flavorful antidote to any so-so skewers you’ve had before.
content: Good morning. Naz Deravian brought us a great new recipe for chicken satay (above), adapted from one developed by the Canadian cookbook author and YouTube personality Pailin Chongchitnant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Judge Rules Trump Can’t Fire Head of Federal Watchdog Agency Without Cause
description: A federal judge said that the president’s efforts to remove Hampton Dellinger, who leads the Office of Special Counsel, were unlawful. The agency protects whistle-blowers.
content: A federal judge in Washington on Saturday blocked President Trump from ousting the leader of a federal watchdog agency, saying that the effort to remove the official without due cause had violated the law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: N.Y. State Police Investigate Death of Another Inmate at Upstate Prison
description: A 22-year-old inmate at Mid-State Correctional Facility in Marcy, N.Y., died Saturday. Nine inmates said he was viciously beaten by corrections officers.
content: The State Police are investigating the death of a prisoner over the weekend in a facility near the central New York prison where another inmate was fatally beaten by guards in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattathias Schwartz and Zach Montague
title: Federal Judges Are Ordering Trump to Slow Down. Will He Listen?
description: Inside the nation’s courthouses, administration lawyers are now facing 100 lawsuits. Outside, the White House is mounting political attacks on judges who rule against it.
content: Justice Department lawyers, confronting an onslaught of legal challenges, have made a case in court that expansive executive power inherent in the Constitution buttresses the lawfulness of President Trump’s aggressive unilateral actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Graff and Simon J. Levien
title: Wildfires Break Out in the Carolinas, Prompting Evacuations
description: The blazes were fueled by gusty winds, dry air and unusually high temperatures. The largest fire was burning 1,600 acres near Myrtle Beach on Sunday.
content: Firefighters on Sunday began to gain an upper hand on more than 170 wildfires in North and South Carolina that had prompted evacuations, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: One More Chance to See the ‘Wicked’ Stars in Pink and Green
description: Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo spent months holding true to a theme during interviews and at awards shows, and they saved stunning options for the Oscars.
content: In the words of Glinda, pink goes good with green.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: Rubio Attacks Zelensky, Firmly Defending Trump and Vance
description: Facing a wave of criticism from his former Senate colleagues, Secretary of State Marco Rubio backed the complaints lobbed by President Trump and Vice President JD Vance against Ukraine’s leader.
content: Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Sunday fiercely defended President Trump’s sharp turn against Ukraine’s leader, accusing President Volodymyr Zelensky of trying to derail the peace process with Russia by openly challenging Mr. Trump and Vice President JD Vance in a heated televised exchange from the Oval Office.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘It Was Clear That No One Really Wanted to Be on the Train’
description: Squeezed onto the express like silent sardines, adopting a barber and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie Aims to ‘Write a Wrong’ in ‘Dream Count’
description: In her first novel since “Americanah,” she draws on a real-life assault as she follows the lives of three Nigerian women and one of their former housekeepers.
content: “Dream Count,” Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie’s first novel in a dozen years, is dreamy indeed: an accumulation of scenes and sensations, cloudlike in their contour, floating this way and that against the backdrop of the pandemic that messed up sleep — and time itself — for us all. But embedded a little more than halfway through is a nightmare, a thunderbolt.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inside the Making of ‘Wicked’
description: One day, several decades ago, the writer Winnie Holzman was shopping in a Manhattan bookstore when a particular cover caught her eye. It showed a woman with a green face, a black hat pulled down over her eyes. The book was “Wicked” by Gregory Maguire, a retelling of L. Frank Baum’s “Oz” stories from the perspective of the Wicked Witch of the West. “When I turned it over and read the little précis on the back, it blew my mind,” Holzman said. “I thought it was such a brilliant premise.” The book ended up on Holzman’s bookshelf, with its enigmatic cover facing out. Years later, the composer Stephen Schwartz contacted Holzman to ask if she’d be interested in adapting Maguire’s book for the stage. The musical they wrote together opened in 2003, and it is now one of the most successful shows in Broadway history. The producers started talking about a movie adaptation, but Holzman was cautious: “We had to really kind of clear our minds and kind of reconceive the whole story.” The film version of “Wicked” opened in 2024, starring Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande, and with a screenplay by Holzman and Dana Fox. It is one of the highest-grossing movies of the year and is nominated for 10 Academy Awards, including best picture. Holzman joins Gilbert Cruz, the editor of The New York Times Book Review, to discuss the benefits and drawbacks of adapting your own adaptation.
content: One day, several decades ago, the writer Winnie Holzman was shopping in a Manhattan bookstore when a particular cover caught her eye. It showed a woman with a green face, a black hat pulled down over her eyes. The book was “Wicked” by Gregory Maguire, a retelling of L. Frank Baum’s “Oz” stories from the perspective of the Wicked Witch of the West. “When I turned it over and read the little précis on the back, it blew my mind,” Holzman said. “I thought it was such a brilliant premise.” The book ended up on Holzman’s bookshelf, with its enigmatic cover facing out. Years later, the composer Stephen Schwartz contacted Holzman to ask if she’d be interested in adapting Maguire’s book for the stage. The musical they wrote together opened in 2003, and it is now one of the most successful shows in Broadway history. The producers started talking about a movie adaptation, but Holzman was cautious: “We had to really kind of clear our minds and kind of reconceive the whole story.” The film version of “Wicked” opened in 2024, starring Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande, and with a screenplay by Holzman and Dana Fox. It is one of the highest-grossing movies of the year and is nominated for 10 Academy Awards, including best picture. Holzman joins Gilbert Cruz, the editor of The New York Times Book Review, to discuss the benefits and drawbacks of adapting your own adaptation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall, Karen Hanley and Claire Hogan
title: 4 Thriller Novels We Recommend
description: Sarah Lyall, who writes the monthly thrillers column for The New York Times Book Review, recommends four of her favorite thriller novels.
content: Sarah Lyall, who writes the monthly thrillers column for The New York Times Book Review, recommends four of her favorite thriller novels.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is Bob Dylan Still a ‘Complete Unknown’?
description: Elijah Wald’s 2015 book, “Dylan Goes Electric! Newport, Seeger, Dylan and the Night That Split the Sixties,” traces the events that led up to Bob Dylan’s memorable performance at the 1965 Newport Folk Festival. The book is about Dylan, but also about the folk movement, youth culture, politics and the record business. For the writer and director James Mangold, Wald’s work provided an opportunity to tell an unusual story about the musician. “You could structure a screenplay along the lines of what Peter Shaffer did with “Amadeus,’” Mangold told The New York Times Book Review editor Gilbert Cruz. “I don’t really know what I learned about Mozart watching ‘Amadeus.’ But I do know that I learned a lot about how we mortals feel about people with immense talent.” Mangold’s film “A Complete Unknown” is a chronicle of Dylan’s early years on the New York folk scene, and it avoids easy explanations for the musician’s genius and success. “What if the thing we don’t understand, we just don’t want to understand,” said Mangold, “which is that he’s actually different? That he’s just a different kind of person than you or I?” In the second episode of our special series devoted to Oscar-nominated films adapted from books, Cruz talks with Mangold about making a film centered on one of music’s most enigmatic figures.
content: Elijah Wald’s 2015 book, “Dylan Goes Electric! Newport, Seeger, Dylan and the Night That Split the Sixties,” traces the events that led up to Bob Dylan’s memorable performance at the 1965 Newport Folk Festival. The book is about Dylan, but also about the folk movement, youth culture, politics and the record business. For the writer and director James Mangold, Wald’s work provided an opportunity to tell an unusual story about the musician. “You could structure a screenplay along the lines of what Peter Shaffer did with “Amadeus,’” Mangold told The New York Times Book Review editor Gilbert Cruz. “I don’t really know what I learned about Mozart watching ‘Amadeus.’ But I do know that I learned a lot about how we mortals feel about people with immense talent.” Mangold’s film “A Complete Unknown” is a chronicle of Dylan’s early years on the New York folk scene, and it avoids easy explanations for the musician’s genius and success. “What if the thing we don’t understand, we just don’t want to understand,” said Mangold, “which is that he’s actually different? That he’s just a different kind of person than you or I?” In the second episode of our special series devoted to Oscar-nominated films adapted from books, Cruz talks with Mangold about making a film centered on one of music’s most enigmatic figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold, Laura Bult, Claire Hogan, James Surdam and Jordan Gantz
title: Musk’s Cost-Saving Claims Are Wrong in So Many Ways
description: We found huge errors in the “wall of receipts” for Elon Musk’s so-called Department of Government Efficiency, where the group lists what it has saved by canceling federal contracts. After The New York Times and other news organizations pointed out the errors, the team quietly removed all five of the largest savings it originally claimed. But David A. Fahrenthold, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, describes how Mr. Musk’s group then added new errors.
content: We found huge errors in the “wall of receipts” for Elon Musk’s so-called Department of Government Efficiency, where the group lists what it has saved by canceling federal contracts. After The New York Times and other news organizations pointed out the errors, the team quietly removed all five of the largest savings it originally claimed. But David A. Fahrenthold, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, describes how Mr. Musk’s group then added new errors.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Adapting the Twists and Turns of ‘Conclave’
description: The screenwriter Peter Straughan has become adept at taking well known — and beloved — books and adapting them for the big and small screens. He was first nominated for an Oscar for his screenplay of the 2011 film “Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy,” based on the classic John le Carré spy novel, and then adapted Hilary Mantel’s “Wolf Hall” trilogy into an award-winning season of television, with an adaptation of the third novel coming out soon. Now he has been nominated for a second Oscar: for his screenplay for “Conclave,” based on Robert Harris’s political thriller set in the secret world of a papal election.“It’s almost like mosaic work,” Straughan tells Gilbert Cruz, the editor of The New York Times Book Review, about adapting books. “You have all these pieces; sometimes they’re going to be laid out in a very similar order to the book, sometimes a completely different order. Sometimes you’re going to deconstruct and rebuild completely.” In this episode of our special series devoted to Oscar-nominated films adapted from books, Cruz talks with Straughan about his process of translating a book to the screen, and about the moments in ‘‘Conclave” that he found most exciting to adapt.
content: The screenwriter Peter Straughan has become adept at taking well known — and beloved — books and adapting them for the big and small screens. He was first nominated for an Oscar for his screenplay of the 2011 film “Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy,” based on the classic John le Carré spy novel, and then adapted Hilary Mantel’s “Wolf Hall” trilogy into an award-winning season of television, with an adaptation of the third novel coming out soon. Now he has been nominated for a second Oscar: for his screenplay for “Conclave,” based on Robert Harris’s political thriller set in the secret world of a papal election.“It’s almost like mosaic work,” Straughan tells Gilbert Cruz, the editor of The New York Times Book Review, about adapting books. “You have all these pieces; sometimes they’re going to be laid out in a very similar order to the book, sometimes a completely different order. Sometimes you’re going to deconstruct and rebuild completely.” In this episode of our special series devoted to Oscar-nominated films adapted from books, Cruz talks with Straughan about his process of translating a book to the screen, and about the moments in ‘‘Conclave” that he found most exciting to adapt.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How ‘Nickel Boys’ Became One of the Year’s Most Visually Striking Films
description: When the filmmaker and photographer RaMell Ross first read “The Nickel Boys,” Colson Whitehead’s Pulitzer Prize-winning novel about two Black boys in a dangerous reform school in the 1960s, he couldn’t help but put himself in the shoes of its protagonists, Elwood and Turner. In his film adaptation of the book, Ross does that to the audience: You see what the characters see, because it’s filmed from the main character’s point of view. “I wondered,” Ross said, “how do you explicitly film from the perspective of a Black person?” It was an experiment that has paid off in critical acclaim. “Nickel Boys” has been nominated for two Academy Awards: best adapted screenplay and best picture. In our special series devoted to Oscar-nominated films adapted from books, “The Book Review” podcast host Gilbert Cruz talks with Ross about why he made the film this particular way.
content: When the filmmaker and photographer RaMell Ross first read “The Nickel Boys,” Colson Whitehead’s Pulitzer Prize-winning novel about two Black boys in a dangerous reform school in the 1960s, he couldn’t help but put himself in the shoes of its protagonists, Elwood and Turner. In his film adaptation of the book, Ross does that to the audience: You see what the characters see, because it’s filmed from the main character’s point of view. “I wondered,” Ross said, “how do you explicitly film from the perspective of a Black person?” It was an experiment that has paid off in critical acclaim. “Nickel Boys” has been nominated for two Academy Awards: best adapted screenplay and best picture. In our special series devoted to Oscar-nominated films adapted from books, “The Book Review” podcast host Gilbert Cruz talks with Ross about why he made the film this particular way.
source.name: The New York Times
